event: 1943 - The U.S. Navy patrol torpedo boat PT-109, commanded by Lieutenant (junior grade) John F. Kennedy, is rammed and sunk by the Japanese destroyer Amagiri off the Solomon Islands.

1990 - Iraq invades Kuwait, leading to the beginning of the Persian Gulf War. The U.S. would launch Operation Desert Shield five days later to defend Saudi Arabia and prepare for the liberation of Kuwait.
1958 - The U.S. nuclear submarine USS Nautilus completes the first-ever undersea voyage to the geographic North Pole, a significant Cold War achievement demonstrating nuclear deterrence capabilities.
1790 - The U.S. Coast Guard is founded as the Revenue-Marine by Secretary of the Treasury Alexander Hamilton, making it the oldest continuous seagoing service of the United States.
1864 - During the Battle of Mobile Bay, Union Admiral David Farragut famously orders, 'Damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead!' leading to a decisive victory for the Union Navy.
1945 - The B-29 bomber 'Enola Gay' of the U.S. Army Air Forces drops the atomic bomb 'Little Boy' on the city of Hiroshima, Japan, in an effort to end World War II.
1782 - General George Washington establishes the Badge of Military Merit to honor soldiers for 'any singularly meritorious action.' It is the direct predecessor of the modern Purple Heart.
1918 - The Battle of Amiens begins, marking the start of the Hundred Days Offensive, the Allied counterattack that would ultimately lead to the end of World War I.
1945 - The B-29 bomber 'Bockscar' drops the atomic bomb 'Fat Man' on the city of Nagasaki, Japan. Japan would announce its surrender six days later.
1949 - The National Security Act Amendments of 1949 are signed, transforming the National Military Establishment into the modern, centralized Department of Defense.
1972 - The last U.S. ground combat unit departs from South Vietnam, ending more than seven years of direct American military engagement in the Vietnam War.
1981 - IBM introduces the Personal Computer (PC), a technology that would revolutionize everything from civilian life to military command, control, and intelligence operations.
1942 - The 'Manhattan Project' is formally established to develop the atomic bomb, a top-secret endeavor combining the efforts of U.S., British, and Canadian scientists and military personnel.
1945 - President Harry S. Truman announces Japan's unconditional surrender, effectively ending World War II. The day becomes known as Victory over Japan Day, or V-J Day.

1914 - The Panama Canal officially opens, a monumental engineering feat that dramatically shortens maritime travel between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, holding immense strategic value for the U.S. Navy.
1954 - The first issue of 'Sports Illustrated' is published. Its iconic 'swimsuit issue' would later become a staple in care packages for deployed U.S. service members.
1942 - U.S. Marines from the 2nd Raider Battalion, led by Lt. Col. Evans Carlson, conduct a daring raid on Makin Atoll in the Pacific, an early special operations mission of WWII.
1965 - Operation Starlite begins in Vietnam. It is the first major offensive conducted purely by U.S. ground forces, marking a significant escalation of American involvement.
1981 - Two U.S. Navy F-14 Tomcats shoot down two Libyan Su-22 fighter jets over the Gulf of Sidra, after the Libyan aircraft fired upon the American planes in international airspace.

1998 - The U.S. military launches cruise missile strikes (Operation Infinite Reach) against al-Qaeda camps in Afghanistan and a chemical plant in Sudan in retaliation for the bombings of U.S. embassies in Africa.
1831 - Nat Turner's slave rebellion begins in Virginia, a violent uprising that was ultimately suppressed by state militia and led to stricter laws and heightened tensions in the antebellum South.
1942 - Brazil declares war on the Axis powers after several of its merchant ships are sunk by German U-boats, becoming the only South American country to send combat troops to the European theater.
1996 - Osama bin Laden issues his first fatwa, a 'Declaration of War against the Americans Occupying the Land of the Two Holy Places,' setting the stage for future attacks against the U.S.
1814 - During the War of 1812, British forces capture Washington, D.C., and set fire to numerous public buildings, including the White House and the Capitol Building.
1944 - Allied forces, including the French 2nd Armored Division and the U.S. 4th Infantry Division, liberate the city of Paris from German occupation.

1920 - The 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is certified, granting women the right to vote. This was a critical step towards the full integration of women into all aspects of American society, including the armed forces.
1955 - The first edition of the 'Guinness Book of World Records' is published. Military-related records, from longest sniper kill to fastest jet, have been a recurring feature.
1963 - Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his iconic 'I Have a Dream' speech during the March on Washington. Many veterans of the armed forces were key participants in the Civil Rights Movement.
2005 - Hurricane Katrina makes landfall in Louisiana, leading to one of the largest domestic deployments of the U.S. National Guard and active-duty military in American history for disaster relief.

1963 - The Moscow-Washington hotline, a direct communication link between the leaders of the U.S. and the Soviet Union, becomes operational. Its purpose was to de-escalate tensions and prevent accidental nuclear war.

1991 - The U.S. Strategic Air Command (SAC), the force responsible for America's nuclear bomber and missile arsenal throughout the Cold War, is officially stood down, reflecting the changing geopolitical landscape.
1939 - Germany invades Poland, initiating World War II in Europe. This event would ultimately draw the United States into the largest and deadliest conflict in human history.
